1.learning_goal: Foundations of Modern AI: In this unit, you will build a clear, practical mental model of what AI is, how it evolved from rule-based to data-driven systems, how symbolic and statistical approaches differ, where ML, DL, and LLMs fit in, and how real-world AI applications depend on data, so you can correctly identify and explain AI systems in everyday tools and industry scenarios.

chapters.title: What AI Really Is
chapters.learning_goals: Understand what makes a system “intelligent” in practice, how AI differs from traditional software, and how AI has evolved from rule-based systems to data-driven approaches—then apply this understanding to real-world examples and timelines.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: What Is Artificial Intelligence?
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define Artificial Intelligence in practical, non-sci-fi terms; Identify what makes a system “intelligent” in practice; Distinguish AI systems from traditional software

lessons.title: A Short History of AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Describe how early AI systems were built; Explain why early AI relied on rules and logic; Identify what changed when data became central

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Spotting AI in Everyday Tools
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to correctly identify whether a system is AI or traditional software and justify your reasoning in practical terms. Output: A completed worksheet/table where each example is labeled as AI or non-AI with a short explanation.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Tracing the Evolution of AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to place key AI developments on a timeline and explain how the shift from rules to data changed AI systems. Output: A labeled timeline and a short comparison paragraph contrasting rule-focused and data-focused eras.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Rule-Based vs Data-Driven AI
chapters.learning_goals: Understand the core differences between rule-based (symbolic) and data-driven (statistical) AI, including how each is built, where each shines, and their limitations. Practice both approaches by designing a small rule engine and a simple pattern-based recommender, then reflect and ask questions in live sessions.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Rule-Based AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define rule-based (symbolic) AI; Explain how rules are written and applied; Identify strengths and limitations of rule-based systems

lessons.title: Data-Driven AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define data-driven (statistical) AI; Explain how data replaces explicit rules; Describe why data-driven systems scale better

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Coffee Shop Rule Engine
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will design and test a small rule-based system that applies discount and recommendation rules in a fictional coffee shop. Output: A simple rule table or pseudocode that, given an order description, outputs which discount or suggestion applies.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie Recommender by Data Patterns
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will simulate a data-driven system by using example viewing data to infer simple “if-likely-then-recommend” patterns without writing explicit rules first. Output: A filled decision sheet that, given a user’s past watched movies, outputs a recommended next movie based on observed patterns.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: What Today’s AI Really Is
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to distinguish symbolic vs statistical AI and narrow vs general AI, apply these distinctions to real-world examples, and debunk common myths about what current AI systems can and cannot do.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Symbolic vs Statistical AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Clearly distinguish symbolic AI from statistical AI; Compare how each approach handles complexity; Identify which approach powers most modern AI systems

lessons.title: Narrow AI vs General AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define Narrow AI using real-world examples; Define General AI conceptually and explain why it does not exist today; Correct common misconceptions about AI capabilities

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Symbolic vs Statistical Sorting Game
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to classify AI examples as symbolic or statistical and explain how each handles complexity in a short justification. Output: A completed sorting chart with each example placed under “Symbolic AI” or “Statistical AI” plus brief reasoning notes.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Narrow vs General AI Reality Check
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will distinguish narrow AI from hypothetical general AI using real-world scenarios and correct common misconceptions. Output: A completed set of scenario labels (Narrow/General/Not AI) and a short myth-vs-reality Q&A sheet.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Modern AI in Practice
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to distinguish ML, deep learning, and LLMs, connect them to real-world applications across industries, and explain how data and data quality shape AI behavior using clear, accurate terminology.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: ML, DL, and LLMs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and LLMs; Explain how these approaches relate to statistical AI; Use correct terminology when describing modern systems

lessons.title: AI in the Real World
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify real-world applications of AI across industries; Describe what type of data these systems rely on; Explain why AI behavior depends on data quality

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: ML, DL, and LLMs Flashcard Lab
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will create and use concept flashcards to accurately match descriptions and examples to Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and LLMs. Output: A small deck of labeled flashcards and a completed matching exercise linking each real-world system to ML, DL, or LLMs.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: AI in Industries Case File
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will analyze short case descriptions to identify the AI type involved, the data it relies on, and how data quality shapes its behavior. Output: A set of completed “case files” where each case includes the AI category, data sources, and at least one risk or effect of poor data quality.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

2.learning_goal: Tables in Practice: In this unit, students will load real datasets into Pandas, navigate DataFrames and Series, select and filter rows and columns, group and aggregate data, create and verify derived columns, and reason about data quality and table transformations well enough to write small analysis scripts and explain their logic in plain language.

chapters.title: Working with Pandas Tables
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to load real-world data into Pandas DataFrames, understand the roles of rows, columns, and Series, and confidently inspect and navigate tabular data using code and small practice projects.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: DataFrames and Series
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define DataFrame and Series using tabular data examples; Explain how rows and columns map to DataFrame structure; Navigate and inspect basic DataFrame components

lessons.title: Loading Real Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Load CSV data into a Pandas DataFrame; Verify that data loaded correctly using inspection methods; Identify basic issues immediately after loading data

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe orders DataFrame
lessons.learning_outcomes: Load a small CSV of cafe orders into a DataFrame, inspect its rows and columns, and confidently navigate Series and DataFrame components. Output: A script that loads a cafe_orders.csv file, prints basic info, head, column names, and selected Series to the console.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music playlist Series explorer
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create DataFrames and Series from a small in-memory music playlist, then explore and compare how row and column access works. Output: A script that builds a playlist DataFrame from Python lists/dicts and prints specific Series, rows, and slices with labeled explanations.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Reading and Filtering Data
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to carefully inspect tabular datasets, identify basic data issues, and describe what the data represents. Practice selecting columns and filtering rows with clear logical conditions to answer plain-language questions using real CSV files.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Reading Data Carefully
lessons.learning_outcomes: Inspect datasets to understand structure and content; Identify potential data issues by scanning rows and columns; Formulate simple questions about what the data represents

lessons.title: Selecting and Filtering
lessons.learning_outcomes: Select specific columns from a DataFrame intentionally; Filter rows using logical conditions; Explain filtering logic clearly in plain language

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie ratings filter
lessons.learning_outcomes: Carefully inspect a movie ratings dataset, then select and filter columns/rows to answer plain-language questions about the data. Output: A script that reads a movie_ratings.csv file and prints filtered views such as “highly rated recent movies” and “low-rated long movies”.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Fitness tracker day log
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice reading a fitness tracking CSV, identifying potential data issues, and applying logical filters to focus on specific days or activity levels. Output: A script that loads daily_steps.csv and prints subsets like “days over 10,000 steps” or “weekend days only” along with column selections.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Grouping and Enriching Data
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to group data with pandas, compute and interpret basic aggregations, and create useful derived columns you can trust in real-world summaries.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Grouping Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Group data by categorical features using Pandas; Apply basic aggregations such as mean and count; Interpret grouped results in terms of real-world meaning

lessons.title: Derived Columns
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create new columns derived from existing data; Explain why derived columns can make data more useful; Verify correctness of newly created columns

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Supermarket sales summary - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Group supermarket sales data by categorical columns and compute basic aggregations, then interpret the grouped results in real-world terms. Output: A script that loads supermarket_sales.csv and prints grouped tables such as total and average sales per store or per product category.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Supermarket sales summary - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Add derived columns to the supermarket sales data (e.g., total_price, discount_rate) and verify their correctness before reusing them in grouped summaries. Output: A script that extends supermarket_sales.csv with new calculated columns and prints checks and summaries that rely on those columns.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Thinking in Tables and Data Quality
chapters.learning_goals: Build confidence reasoning about data in rows and columns, predicting how operations reshape tables, and applying essential data quality checks before analysis. Practice these skills through scenario-based exercises, discussions, and Q&A with instructors and peers.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Thinking in Tables
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reason about data transformations in terms of rows and columns; Predict how operations will change a dataset’s structure; Develop confidence manipulating tabular data logically

lessons.title: Data Quality Checks
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand different data quality checks and why they are important; Perform basic checks to assess data quality; Explain why quality checks should happen before analysis

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Thinking in tables quiz
lessons.learning_outcomes: Strengthen your ability to mentally model how tabular operations change rows and columns by working through written scenarios and predicting resulting table structures. Output: A completed quiz-style worksheet (text answers) where you match operations to before/after tables and explain the transformations.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Data quality checks detective
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice identifying and prioritizing data quality checks through scenario-based questions, deciding what to check and why before any analysis. Output: A written set of answers where you list appropriate quality checks for given datasets, explain their importance, and spot potential data issues.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

3.learning_goal: Data Cleaning to EDA: In this unit, students will clean and type-correct real datasets, detect and interpret outliers, apply purposeful filtering and grouping, and carry out basic exploratory data analysis with appropriate plots and summaries to answer focused questions without over-interpreting results.

chapters.title: Cleaning Types and Taming Outliers
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to spot and fix incorrect data types, investigate outliers with simple visual and numeric tools, and decide when unusual values are meaningful signals or problems to address in real-world datasets.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Fixing Data Types
lessons.learning_outcomes: Detect columns with incorrect data types; Convert data types to enable proper analysis; Explain why correct data types are essential

lessons.title: Detecting and Understanding Outliers
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify outliers using simple numerical and visual methods; Distinguish between meaningful outliers and problematic outliers; Explain why outliers should be investigated, not automatically removed

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe orders data cleanup
lessons.learning_outcomes: Clean a messy cafe orders dataset by fixing incorrect data types and explaining why each correction matters for analysis. Output: A cleaned table of cafe orders where dates, prices, and quantities have correct data types and can be analyzed without errors.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie ratings outlier detective
lessons.learning_outcomes: Analyze movie ratings and box office data to detect, visualize, and interpret outliers, deciding which are meaningful vs problematic. Output: A short report and plots highlighting outlier movies with explanations of why they stand out and how they should be treated in analysis.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Filtering and Grouping for Insight
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to filter and group datasets with clear intent so you can answer targeted questions, explain your choices, and validate the results. Practice these skills on realistic scenarios like fitness app users and online store sales to spot patterns and communicate findings confidently.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Filtering with Purpose
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply filters based on meaningful conditions; Explain why specific filters are applied; Validate that filtering produced expected results

lessons.title: Grouping for Insight
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use grouping to compare categories in data; Interpret aggregated values meaningfully; Identify patterns revealed through grouping

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Fitness app user filtering
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use purposeful filtering on a fitness tracking dataset to answer targeted questions, justify filter choices, and verify filtered results. Output: A filtered dataset and summary answering questions like “who are active users?” with checks that confirm filters worked as intended.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Online store sales grouping
lessons.learning_outcomes: Group online store transactions by categories (e.g., product type, region) to compute aggregates, interpret them, and identify meaningful patterns. Output: Grouped summary tables and simple charts showing which categories drive sales and how they compare.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Exploratory Data Analysis in Action
chapters.learning_goals: Learn what exploratory data analysis (EDA) is, why it comes before modeling and decisions, and how it differs from final conclusions. Practice creating and interpreting basic matplotlib plots to explore real datasets and clearly communicate EDA findings.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: What EDA Really Means
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define exploratory data analysis in clear, practical terms; Explain the goals of EDA before modeling or decisions; Distinguish EDA from final conclusions

lessons.title: First Plots for Insight
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create basic plots using matplotlib; Choose plot types appropriate to specific questions; Interpret plots to describe trends and patterns

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: EDA concepts check
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish clearly between exploratory data analysis, modeling, and final conclusions through matching, scenario analysis, and reflection questions. Output: A completed written/quiz-style worksheet categorizing tasks as EDA or not and explaining EDA goals in your own words.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music app listening patterns plots
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create and interpret basic matplotlib plots (e.g., histograms, bar charts, line plots) to explore listening behavior in a music app dataset. Output: A small set of plots with brief written interpretations describing trends and patterns in user listening habits.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Seeing Patterns in Data
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to recognize patterns and anomalies in data, distinguish variable types and question types, and choose appropriate summaries and visualizations to describe findings clearly without over-interpreting.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Patterns and Anomalies
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify patterns emerging from data exploration; Detect anomalies and unusual values; Explain findings clearly without over-interpreting

lessons.title: Data Types & “What am I analyzing?”
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish numerical vs categorical variables; Identify whether a question is univariate or relationship-based; Understand that choosing appropriate summary statistics and visualizations is based on data type and get an overview of main techniques according to data type

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Ride-sharing patterns explorer
lessons.learning_outcomes: Examine ride-sharing data to identify recurring patterns and anomalies, then describe findings clearly without overstating conclusions. Output: A concise analysis with tables/plots marking typical patterns (e.g., rush hours) and unusual values (e.g., extreme fares or durations) plus explanations.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Variable types and question matching
lessons.learning_outcomes: Classify variables as numerical or categorical, match questions to univariate or relationship-based analysis, and choose suitable summaries/visuals by type. Output: A completed matching and reasoning exercise that maps each variable and question to appropriate summary statistics and visualization types.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

4.learning_goal: Variability, Relationships, and Uncertainty: In this unit, students build intuitive statistical thinking by comparing variability and noise, exploring relationships between two or more variables (including correlation vs causation), and using probability and sampling ideas to judge how much to trust patterns in real-world data.

chapters.title: Variability, Noise, and Real Data
chapters.learning_goals: Build an intuitive feel for how spread and standard deviation describe variability, and learn to spot when patterns in real-world data are likely just random noise rather than meaningful signal.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Variability & Standard Deviation (Intuition)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain variability as how spread out values are; Interpret standard deviation at an intuitive level; Compare two datasets and infer which has more variability

lessons.title: Randomness, Noise & Why patterns can be misleading
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define randomness and noise in real datasets; Recognize when a pattern may be caused by noise rather than signal; Explain why repeated measurements or samples may lead to different results

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe order variability
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice intuitively comparing variability and standard deviation by analyzing how spread out daily cafe orders are across different weeks. Output: A short written comparison or simple script that labels which week has higher variability and explains why in plain language.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Fitness tracker noise detector
lessons.learning_outcomes: Strengthen intuition about randomness and noise by examining day-to-day step counts to decide which apparent patterns are likely just random fluctuation. Output: A short written analysis or simple script that flags “suspicious patterns” that may be noise and explains your reasoning.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Seeing Relationships Between Variables
chapters.learning_goals: Build intuitive and practical skill in bivariate thinking by exploring how two variables move together, choosing appropriate visualizations, and interpreting correlation (Pearson vs Spearman) in real datasets with outliers and non-linear patterns.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Bivariate Thinking - Relationships between two variables
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify when a question requires bivariate analysis; Choose an appropriate visualization for different variable type combinations; Describe what it means for two variables to move together at an intuitive level

lessons.title: Correlation - Pearson vs Spearman (High level)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define correlation and interpret positive vs negative correlation; Differentiate Pearson (linear) vs Spearman (rank or monotonic) at a high level; Explain when Spearman may be more appropriate than Pearson

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music app bivariate explorer
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply bivariate thinking by choosing appropriate visualizations to explore relationships (e.g., song length vs. number of plays, genre vs. likes) in a fictional music app dataset. Output: A set of sketched or coded plots (or descriptions of them) with brief notes on what each suggests about the relationship.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Study hours and grades correlation
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build intuition for Pearson vs Spearman correlation by comparing linear vs rank-based relationships between study hours and test scores, including cases with outliers and non-linear patterns. Output: A short report or script that computes/compares Pearson and Spearman values and states which is more appropriate in each scenario.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Thinking Beyond Correlation
chapters.learning_goals: Build intuition for why correlation does not imply causation and how relationships can change when you consider additional variables. Learn to spot common pitfalls (like confounders and reverse causality) and practice multivariate thinking that connects directly to feature selection and high‑level ML modeling decisions.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Correlation ≠ Causation
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain why correlation does not imply causation; Identify common pitfalls such as confounders and reverse causality; Propose ways to reduce wrong conclusions, such as checking other variables and using domain reasoning

lessons.title: Multivariate Intuition - When relationships change
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain why adding a third variable can change an observed relationship; Describe controlling for another variable conceptually; Understand how multivariate thinking connects to feature selection and ML modeling decisions at a high level

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Correlation trap quiz
lessons.learning_outcomes: Deepen understanding of why correlation ≠ causation by working through scenarios that involve confounders, reverse causality, and misleading headlines. Output: A completed quiz or answer sheet where each scenario is labeled with the specific pitfall and a brief explanation.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Multivariate story puzzles
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice multivariate intuition by analyzing short story-based puzzles where adding a third variable changes the interpretation of an observed relationship. Output: A written set of answers identifying the third variable, explaining how it changes the relationship, and linking it to how you’d think about features in an ML model.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Probability, Uncertainty, and Samples
chapters.learning_goals: Students will learn to interpret probability as a way of describing real-world uncertainty, and to connect numeric probabilities to everyday language and expected variability. They will also learn to distinguish samples from populations, explain why different samples give different results, and critically assess claims based on small or biased samples.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Probability as Uncertainty (High level)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain probability as a way to describe uncertainty; Interpret probability statements in everyday terms; Connect probability to variability and why results are not exact

lessons.title: Samples vs Population - Why results vary
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish population vs sample intuitively; Explain why different samples give different results; Describe why we should be cautious about trusting patterns from small samples

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Everyday probability scenarios
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reinforce the idea of probability as uncertainty by interpreting probability statements in everyday contexts (weather, games, medical tests) and connecting them to variability. Output: A worksheet-style set of answers translating numeric probabilities into everyday language and noting what kind of variability you’d expect.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Sampling stories
lessons.learning_outcomes: Strengthen intuition about samples vs populations by judging fictional survey setups, explaining why different samples can give different results, and critiquing small-sample claims. Output: A written critique for each scenario that identifies the population, describes the sample, and explains how sampling could distort the observed pattern.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges
